title: 107_s969
content: SECTION 1. FINDINGS. Congress finds that Lyme disease is a common bacterial infection transmitted by tick bites. Early detection is crucial as it can cause serious health issues if left untreated, affecting various organs and systems. Lyme disease accounts for 90 percent of all vector-borne infections in the United States, but ticks also spread other disorders like ehrlichiosis and babesiosis. Tick-borne disease cases have been reported in 49 states, with 90 percent in 10 states including Connecticut, Pennsylvania, and New York. Studies suggest the actual number of cases is much higher than reported. The actual number of Lyme disease cases is much higher than reported due to poor surveillance, making treatment difficult for many patients with persistent symptoms. Establishment of a Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee. Establishment of the Tick-Borne Disorders Advisory Committee to advise on interagency coordination, collaboration with other organizations, and responses to constituency groups regarding efforts to address tick-borne disorders. The Secretary of Health and Human Services appoints voting members to the Committee from various member groups including the scientific community, tick-borne disorder organizations, health care providers, patients with tick-borne illnesses, and representatives of state and local health departments. The Committee appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services includes voting members from different groups, with an equal number from each group. Ex officio members are also included. The Assistant Secretary of Health and a public co-chairperson chosen by the members serve as co-chairpersons for a 2-year term with voting rights. All members serve 4-year terms, and vacancies are filled as needed. The Committee appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services includes voting members from different groups, with an equal number from each group. Ex officio members are also included. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members may serve after their terms expire until successors take office. The Committee holds public meetings at least twice a year, with additional meetings as needed. Agenda items can be added by Committee members or co-chairpersons. Meetings are conducted as required by laws and regulations, and reports are due annually. The Secretary is required to submit annual reports to Congress on activities under the Act, detailing progress in developing diagnostic tools and promoting public awareness and physician education. $250,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2003 and 2004 for Committee expenses. The Committee incurs expenses and per diem costs in accordance with the Federal Advisory Committee Act, with no voting member being a permanent salaried employee. Authorization for research funding of $10,000,000 annually from 2003 to 2007 for Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders research, education, and prevention efforts. Goals are outlined in the following section. The Senate recommends the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders, in consultation with relevant agencies. The Senate recommends the Secretary of Health and Human Services to establish a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders, including goals for developing diagnostic tests, surveillance, reporting, and prevention strategies. The Senate recommends a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders, including prevention and control of various diseases such as Masters' disease, ehrlichiosis, babesiosis, and others. The Senate passed a five-year plan for activities related to Lyme disease and other tick-borne disorders on October 17, 2002.
